61849898
>>61849447

>>61849447

>most used currency for CP is not however
quit the infighting, monegro.

item.title: >be me, a mid-30s senior manager in a successful global corporation >read The Economist, have one outdoorsy hobby, have… — 8 replies — 29.1/hr
item.content:encoded:
>be me, a mid-30s senior manager in a successful global corporation >read The Economist, have one outdoorsy hobby, have…

Open thread • Replies: 8 • Updated: 2026-02-18 11:45 UTC

OP

>be me, a mid-30s senior manager in a successful global corporation
>read The Economist, have one outdoorsy hobby, have wife and two kids and a shiny new house
>new batch of employees recently started, with ages ranging from 21 to 25
>we expect these graduates to be the future of the company
>I don't directly manage any of them but have oversight of all of them
>a few months after I start I notice something concerning
>90 % of top performers are women
>all of the "needs improvement" employees are male
>all the women have already become involved in valuable company voluntary activities like the Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion board, organising the team's end of financial year party, setting up mental health listening seminars
>one female employee is even on the verge of arranging a famous journalist motivational speaker who specialises in reporting on dictatorships such as Iran, Russia, or Hungary
>male employees do nothing extra
>have been getting reports on a few employees, all male, about them mumbling, not speaking clearly, not networking enough with other business areas
>scheduled lunch with one of them and asked him where he wanted to be in 5 years
>couldn't give me a good, clear, precise answer
>asked same question to our top female new employee
>"I intend to be the leader in emerging market widget supply chain analytics and to have mentored at least 5 under-represented BAME employees to promotions per year, in addition to..." (you get the picture, I had to recommend her for a promotion)

When I ask HR about which employees aren't quite team players, invariably it's the male employees that don't measure up. The HR lead even had to write up one of the employees because he made some wisecrack about "too many pointless meetings"!

But the WORST thing is that ALL the male employees take up remote working as an option if they can... while NONE of the females do this.

Guys, what's the deal?

Early replies (first 3)

61869473
>>61869454
>valuable company voluntary activities
>valuable

61869476
>>61869454
>>61869473
ALSO, gr8 b8 m8

61869483
Believable bait other than
>>all the women have already become involved in valuable company voluntary activities like the Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion board, organising the team's end of financial year party, setting up mental health listening seminars

If you're going to refuse to play just because your difficulty is set to hard mode, don't be surprised when you lose.

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61869491
>>61869454
You need to invite these guys for a couple beers, pull up an 8 ball and the pieces will fall into place.

61869539
>>61869454
men that seek out these sorts of jobs are losers to begin with. day to day work is so far removed and watered down into microtasks that it looses view and connection to its purpose/function/benefit to individual lives and therefore society as a whole. Real men with real motivation and a drive for success seek out work that is tangible. Do A, Then Do B. Put A and B Together, It makes C. C makes a persons life better/easier/less stressful.

The men in your company don't see or understand the point of what you're all doing, and thats exactly why they are there. Because they want a job they don't have to care about that ideally also won't care about them. But their monkey brains get peeved about the pointless meetings because they aren't directly tackling issues, its organizing the organization of microtasks.

To make an example out of this: Here is a company that is trying to bake a cake.
>Okay so step one, we need to whisk the eggs!
>before we do that we need to clean the whisk.
>but where are we getting the cleaning supplies from?
>instead of going to the supermarket we need the highest quality cleaning supplies at the cheapest price
>actually make sure its the best, cheapest cleaning supplies that are for whisks specifically
>to figure that out we need someone to do research to compare different cleaning supplies for whisks
>before we do that we need to make sure that the steel whisk we currently have is able to be cleaned and won't erode when we clean it

Good morning Jerry, Happy Monday, Here's what we're going to get you to do for 3 weeks:
>Do research on this specific type of steel as well as research on this cleaning liquid and find out all of the possible outcomes when these two materials make contact with eachother. Record your finding and present it to us by the end of the month WITH ENTHUSIASM OR ELSE YOU'RE FUCKN SAKED.

>Why should Jerry would give a fuck? He probably doesn't even know the company is trying to bake a cake.

61869547
>>61869454
Males are the obselete genre, they only want to live for simple staring at screens pleasure these days.

61869567
>>61869454
bro you're not observing some deep societal mystery
you're just describing the most predictable corporate midwit NPC behaviour pattern of the last 10 years
women figured out the actual game:
>suck up to HR
>collect every extracurricular checkbox
>memorise the corporate jargon salad
>stay visible 24/7
>never criticise anything out loud
men (especially autistic-leaning or just normal ones) are still playing the 2010 game:
>do good work
>be competent
>go home
and then get told they're "not team players" because they didn't spend 8 unpaid hours making a Canva slideshow about "allyship"
you're not seeing female superiority
you're seeing who optimised hardest for the current midwit corporate signaling meta
and you're mad the men won't LARP as hard as the women
touch grass (your one outdoorsy hobby isn't enough apparently)
retard moron senior manager moment

61869571
>>61869454
all of this is a gay larp written by someone who has never had a job. (i am a late 30s senior manager at a fortune 20 company.)

item.title: I said LLMs are a non-intelligent mechanical confidence trick (con-man) and made a thread the other day saying the bubbl… — 6 replies — 12.5/hr
item.content:encoded:
I said LLMs are a non-intelligent mechanical confidence trick (con-man) and made a thread the other day saying the bubbl…

Open thread • Replies: 6 • Updated: 2026-02-18 11:33 UTC

OP

I said LLMs are a non-intelligent mechanical confidence trick (con-man) and made a thread the other day saying the bubble is already popping.

I realised I’ve made a huge mistake about AI. When I kept telling my imbecile manager that LLMs will never be more intelligent than us, I meant it’ll never be more intelligent than me. It’s already more intelligent than him. I forgot to put myself in his retarded shoes.

This realisation matters because it’s also the case for the majority of money swinging the stock market on a daily basis. Most people are retarded.

So I guess AI stocks surely have to double again until some semblance of financial reality finally has to set in. but right now we’ve got imbecile pajeet CEOs who spent their entire lives working on bullshit AI, who are determined to invest their entire company’s market cap into keeping the puppet show propped up for as long as possible for their own retarded ego.

Microsoft will do to OpenAI what MSTR is doing to bitcoin. Constant stock dilution, money borrowing way more than it can ever pay back, to invest in OpenAI. The show will almost never end until the global debt is in the sextrillions. The billions they've invested so far is fucking nothing. They'll go right to the wire, and the retard-controlled stock market will cheer them on.

And imbeciles will actively push microslop upwards ad-infinitum, believing that we're truly on the cusp of the singularity. Earnings don’t matter, the narrative is all that matters.

What a sick world we live in. Even Marx didn’t foresee capitalism becoming this chronically ill.

Early replies (first 3)

61869324
>>61869316
What exactly is wrong with any of this?

61869336
>>61869316
>im smarter than ai
you barely even understand what it is.
you think you're smarter than it because chatgpt hallucinated to you once but this is like how reddit midwits think atheism is real and true even though it's self-evidently bullshit

61869344
>>61869324
Because it ultimately ends in a government bailout where ordinary people are robbed and indebted forever to the people who caused it and benefitted from it. I didn't think I had to explain that part. AI is still bullshit, and it's still going to collapse, but not until it's completely exhausted all possible avenues of inflating the bubble. It has to suck up every single dollar in the entire universe, rehypothecate the same dollar 50 times over, until it simply can't go any further, then the government prints 100 sextillion dollars, adds it to the national debt, and imposes harsh austerity and taxation on ordinary people to finance it, combined with massive currency devaluation, and people lose their savings.

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61869346
>>61869336
Belief AI can be intelligent and conscious, is the atheist tendency. Your logic is all backwards, because naturally, you are a retard.

61869348
>>61869346
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y4yBvvGi_2A

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NUeybwTMeWo

61869548
>>61869348
>Doesn't even open the banana the way monkeys do.
They open them upside down, by squeezing the nib then tearing. Trust a retard not to know that. Your bananas are probably always mushy and shite because you spend ages wrestling the longer 'tab'.

And obviously none of this shit is relevant, retard

item.title: Is it really that much more difficult to start a business in the eu than us? — 40 replies — 43.7/hr
item.content:encoded:
Is it really that much more difficult to start a business in the eu than us?

Open thread • Replies: 40 • Updated: 2026-02-18 11:06 UTC

OP

You guys in the EU make less than us on paychecks, but you get to keep more of your money because you have universal healthcare and PTO while we have to pay for private insurance which chronically denies people's health situations.

Are people saying that starting a business in the EU is difficult because of the regulations? What regulations does the European union impose on its citizen's than they think it's easier to start in the United States instead?

Early replies (first 3)

61860815
>>61860796
Depends enormously on which country are we talking about. Some are easy (Germany) some are very hard (Italy)

61860817
>>61860796
> you get to keep more of your money because you have universal healthcare
yeah right
good luck getting that "universal healthcare" if you're not a boomer, waiting lists are years for even a basic exam/procedure. It's either you go private (and pay out of your own pocket) or you die
> and PTO
oh wow, 20 wagie cagie free days a year. Totally worth the 60%+ taxes.

All taxation is theft. It's just that. Taxation doesn't pay for services. It's just the way they control the economy, and here in EU they fucking LOVE to control what you can and cannot do. They print the money, they don't need to tax you. They tax you to control you (and to humiliate you)

61860822
>>61860796
The healthcare thing is too much american leftie argument, it also has been very overcrowded by you guessed arabs and africans, unironically I was better treated when I broke my leg in brazil of all places then in france

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61860967
in my country, the one thing one has to look out for is paying for your own social/healthinsurance, ie, if you have your own business, you need to pay taxes for your own health/socialinsurance, and the taxman wont ask you for the first 3y of that business.
After the 3y pass, you will then have to payup all the retrospective social insurance tax costs incurred, which fucks over a lot of retard or unfortunate first business owners

61861032
>>61860837
This is why we need a unified EU business regulation and undermind the corrupt sovereignist that want to keep individual burocratic fuckery.

61861057
>>61860815
>Some are easy (Germany)
> some are very hard (Italy)
let me guess italian never tried germany?
Germany is known to be a bureucracy hellhole with people fleeing to other countries from it.

>>61861032
>unified will fix it
France&germany have been dictating eu lawmaking. You will eat shit as you already do. You have eu wide higher taxes because germany didnt want to compete and made mandatory higher minimum vat a thing.

Not to mention that countries that joined got their industries destroyed by unified regulation and had to import from germany/france what they used to produce themself

61861071
It's the one thing the USA gets right. I personally made a "business" (that never made any profit) in the span of an afternoon. Cost maybe $200 to get my identification numbers for the llc

61861091
>>61861032
yeah let's give the EU bureaucrats more power that will fix it

61861111
>>61860796
>Is it really that much more difficult to start a business in the eu than us?
Depends on the business. If you want to do something shady the US is the place to go. The US has barely any standards and barely any regulations.

61861113
>>61860817
>waiting lists are years for even a basic exam/procedure
What are you talking about? I live currently in the EU and have never had to wait for medical care.

61861119
Us is easier.
I have created 2 corpos and 1 llc for different purposes within the past 8 years. You can do it all online for a few bucks, other regulations depend on specific industry but overall it's pretty easy

61861128
>>61860860
higher taxation alone puts euros at a disadvantage. Its fine if you do a local job since you compete with locals but anything online / shipped its bad since they have to be more efficient than rest of world to reach same profit margin.

As for amount of bureaucracy its fucking complex and depends on what country and what profession. There is even stupid shit like if you run a repair shop and repair inside your building it counts different than if you decide to drive to your customer and repair locally. In the later case they classify you as a handyman worker and will fine you if you didn't register with the craftsman ministry. Also if you do something you didn't register for you will also be fined but you can register as " i will do anything" more broadly and dodge it. The amount of bullshit can easily fill a book.

61861429
>>61860796
Depends on what your goals are, the type of business, your personal goals and the markets you wish to enter. In general it's more of an investment in the long run but if you plan to offer your services or products in the EU anyway it makes sense to start your business here and already be compliant

61861441
>>61860817
>waiting lists are years for even a basic exam/procedure.
Yeah, I remember waiting decades for my appendicitis, it rupturing and me dying because of it. Thankfully they could keep me alive for months despite the extreme difficulties this poses.

>>61861032
We need more unified European regulation. Sadly the EU is not an economic alliance anymore.

61862545
>>61860796
>>61860860

61865504

61865623
>>61860796
>you have universal healthcare
yea but you have to wait 1 year+ because there is a million niggers in queue before you

61865645
>>61861057

Germany and France made the EU suck with their shit like GDPR etc. Spain happily sniffs every turd. The rest aren't better.

61866460

They hate nothing more than citizens that are not dependent on them. That's why they are allowing third world people in to the maximum extent physically possible, that are never going end up being a "plus" on the balance sheet, but that they hope will be cheap voting sheep for their party. The people pay for them after all, not the party.
Effectively: If Elon Musk was a citizen of a EU-country, he'd already be in jail waiting for the sentence to be sent to prison. You probably don't want to get into that situation.

61867577
Europe has no tech industry because German rich fags were afraid to pay coders more than traditional engineers because then car engineers would ask for more money so they just fucked all of Europe and let America and China run everything.

61868041
>>61860796
No, in some places is actually easy, I remember playing a game in class one time in uni to look regulations for business worldwide, there's almost no difference whatsoever in european and american regulations, sometimes american regulations are actually worse and the accumulated taxes from city, state, federal can surpass european taxes. The only conclusion we could draw was that europeans were just lazy and too laidback, they have so much welfare that there's no rush or anxiety with ending up destitute and homeless so they just don't bother with the hazzle of building a business. They are better off just being on benefits or unemployed, most business there predate the big social welfare network just because of a need to survive really and complacency in changing what already works, they are much much better off.
